## Summary statistics for the ABV variable.
```{r Q7, echo=TRUE}
# Subset the data

emp_cat <- data.frame(emp[,(names(Employee_data) %in%
                c("Age","Education","MonthlyIncome","DistanceFromHome","JobInvolvement","JobLevel", "JobSatisfaction",
                  "NumCompaniesWorked", "PercentSalaryHike","PerformanceRating", "StockOptionLevel",
                  "TotalWorkingYears","TrainingTimesLastYear","WorkLifeBalance","RelationshipSatisfaction","YearsAtCompany",
                  "YearsInCurrentRole","Attrition","EmployeeNumber"))])
# Balance the data
require(ROSE)
## Oversample
emp_cat.oversample <- ovun.sample(Attrition ~ ., data = emp_cat, method = "over",N = 2466)$data
table(emp_cat.oversample$Attrition)
## Undersample
emp_cat.undersample <- ovun.sample(Attrition ~ ., data = emp_cat, method = "under",N = 474,seed = 1)$data
table(emp_cat.undersample$Attrition)
## Balanced sample
emp_cat.balancedsample <- ovun.sample(Attrition ~ ., data = emp_cat, method = "both", p=0.5, N=1470, seed = 1)$data
table(emp_cat.balancedsample$Attrition)

# Split data into training and test set
emp_train <- subset(emp_cat, Education < 4)
emp_test <- subset(emp_cat, Education >= 4)

# Select variables (res_vars) for the model to predict 'resigned'
res_vars <- c("Age","Education","MonthlyIncome","DistanceFromHome","JobInvolvement","JobLevel", "JobSatisfaction", "NumCompaniesWorked", "PercentSalaryHike","PerformanceRating", "StockOptionLevel", "TotalWorkingYears","TrainingTimesLastYear", "WorkLifeBalance","RelationshipSatisfaction","YearsAtCompany","YearsInCurrentRole","Attrition")
set.seed(222)
emp_res_rose_RF <- randomForest(Attrition ~ .,
                           data = emp_cat.balancedsample[,names(emp_cat.balancedsample) %in% res_vars],
                           ntree=500, importance = TRUE,
                           na.action = na.omit)
varImpPlot(emp_res_rose_RF,type=1,
           main="Variable Importance (Accuracy)",
           sub = "Random Forest Model")
```
